title: What is the name or title of the project?
description: Provide the official name or working title of the project.
rationale: Establishes a clear identifier for referencing the project in documentation and communication.

title: What is the purpose and scope of the project?
description: Why does this project exist, what problems does it solve, and what are its main features and boundaries?
rationale: Establishes the business context and defines the responsibilities and limitations of the project.

title: Who are the key stakeholders and users of the project?
description: Who uses it, who maintains it, and who makes decisions about it?
rationale: Helps identify priorities, expectations, communication channels, and decision-making authority.

title: What are the core technical components and how do they interact?
description: What is the architecture of the project, which technologies are used, and how do different modules depend on or talk to each other?
rationale: Provides a clear understanding of the systemâ€™s structure and is critical for troubleshooting, scaling, or onboarding new developers.

title: What is the project's lifecycle and how are changes managed?
description: What processes govern development, testing, deployment, and versioning? How are changes tracked and approved?
rationale: Ensures consistency and quality across environments and helps maintain long-term stability.

title: What are the known limitations, issues, and future plans?
description: What technical debts, constraints, or open issues exist? What enhancements or roadmap items are planned?
rationale: Gives visibility into current challenges and supports long-term planning and risk management.
